item.title: By: chakira
item.dc:creator: chakira
item.description: Stroumsa deals with quite a few halakhic examples throughout the book. Among these are: Maimonides's solution to a quarreling couple (borrowed from maliki jurisprudence), Maimonides's putting knowledge of God in Halakha (from Almohads and Avicenna), Maimonides on a woman going to work against husband's wishes (he does not really allow it) and other queries.

item.title: By: chakira
item.dc:creator: chakira
item.description: How about asking why this was the permanent twilight of the Jewish/Muslim encounter in the Mediterranean world? In other words, if we believe Stroumsa, thirty years after Rambam, we get the same misunderstandings we have kept for a thousand years. How did the entire social imaginary of this Mediterranean really just vanish? Or did it?

item.title: By: Izgad
item.dc:creator: Izgad
item.description: I have been reading Joel Kraemer's biography of Maimonides. He also places a lot of emphasis on the Islamic context. I am interested in this issue in terms of Maimonides' non-apocalyptic messianism and possible Fatmid influences.
